2.text: (You step out of the room, and see the maid from earlier waiting outside for you. With a quick glance at you, she begins walking down the corridor—you follow in her footsteps carefully, praying that you’ve understood the cues right.)

3.text: (Who was supposed to lead, master or servant? Ugh, this is a headache.)

4.text: (Why couldn’t you have reawakened as someone that [i]isn’t[/i] expected to know all of these social nuances?)

5.text: (She rounds the corner without a moment’s hesitation. You trail behind her as the two of you emerge at the bannister, heads down, and make a final left turn.)

6.text: (At the end of the hallway, she reaches out to open the door for you.)

7.text: (An elaborate dining hall greets you. Sunlight streams through the windows, settling its rays upon the dark tablecloth, yet the room is freezing.)

8.text: (It’s grand in a way that leaves you feeling more small than awestruck. So many chairs left empty, servants with nothing else to do but stare at the table’s occupants.)

9.text: (You can see two figures already seated, one at the head of the table and the other beside him. They’re placed so far away that you can barely make out their faces.)

10.text: (The maid steps back, taking her place with the other servants lined up against the walls as you walk towards the table. Your footsteps quicken and grow more confident as you spy an empty chair, likely set just for you.)

11.text: (You make your way over and take a seat as gracefully as you can manage.)

12.text: You’ve certainly taken your time this morning.

13.text: (The voice of the man sitting across from you rings clearly the moment you’ve settled into your seat. It borders on harsh, but unless you’re imagining things, there’s also a touch of wry humor embedded within his words.)

14.text: (You raise your head to see just who exactly has decided to criticize you, only to freeze in your spot.)

16.text: (It feels as though ice water has been poured down on your head.)

17.text: (Across from you sits a face you’d never imagine you’d see in the flesh—one so strikingly familiar that you can’t help but sharply inhale and sit there, stunned silly.)

18.text: (You know him. You [i]know[/i] him, and because of that, you know this game. You haven’t played it in years, and got… interrupted the last time you tried to pick it back up, but you could recognize the characters in a heartbeat.)

19.text: (Seeing his face now, you’re definitely sure of it. This is [i]Doki Doki Full Blossom Love ~ When the holy flower blooms under clouded skies.[/i])

20.text: (An otome game wholly unremarkable from the rabble; the same questionable love interest tropes, the same martyrly heroine destined to save the world, and the same two-dimensional villainess determined to get in the way of true love.)

21.text: (...It’s also the game you were about to start playing again in the moments before your death. So this is what that god’s teasing was about…)

25.speaker: The God
25.text: Spin me a story I’ve yet to see, and take your place…

29.text: (You don’t want to admit it, don’t want to entertain this connection, but you know the way this story goes and you know it well. You turn your gaze to your lap, then to the drinking glass settled beside your plate.)

30.text: (You pick it up with a trembling hand.)

31.text: (Even in the warped reflection of the curved glass, you can make out the figure that stares back. [i]It’s you.[/i])

32.text: (It’s still your face, unchanged as ever—the one spot of recognition in an unfamiliar place.)

33.text: (But that must be a lie. Because now you [i]know[/i] who you must be, the body you’re inhabiting, and yet all that you can see is your own face.)

36.text: ([i]Cecilia Antirrhinum de Karmina[/i] is the irredeemable, cruel, and ever-unfathomable villainess of this game whose only destiny is death, [b][i]and her face is now yours.[/i][/b])

37.text: Has your family fallen so far from your favor that you deem us unworthy of a response?

38.text: I don’t know if you realize this, but it’s incredibly rude to leave people waiting for an answer. Attentiveness is a virtue.

39.text: (His teasing has turned to scolding. It seems that you’ve used up all the grace he was willing to give you.)

41.text: Holy One who gives us light… Perhaps we need to refresh your knowledge on table manners, [i]dear sister.[/i]

42.text: (His name finally comes to you. This is Cecilia’s adopted brother, one of the love interests from [i]Full Blossom.[/i])

43.text: (Though a scar mars his cheek, it does little to detract from his normally exuberant, welcoming demeanor.)

44.text: (He shakes his head and puts on his original expression, smiling easily, as if he were born with it. Ever the chivalrous and gallant knight.)

45.text: (He’s Maverick, Maverick Antirrhinum de Karmina. And…)

46.options: ...He was my definitive favorite love interest.,...I enjoyed him a fair bit I'd say. Okay - maybe more than a bit.,...He wasn't my type but he's fine overall.,...It'd be generous to say that I didn't like him as much as the others.

47.text: (Maverick, duty and honor-bound by all means necessary. Rigid at times, but always insistent in repaying his debts. Incredibly adept with the sword, a force to be reckoned with on the battlefield.)

48.text: (That was Maverick, the last true knight of the aristocracy.)

49.text: (And that was [i]your[/i] Maverick, but as you look at him now, you realize it won’t ever be the same as you remember.)

50.text: (You’re his “sister” now, not the saintess. You don’t know how to feel, so all you can do is push down these bubbling emotions and respond to the question you’ve left hanging in the air.)

51.text: (Who doesn’t like a faithful knight of one’s own? Boisterous and outgoing, protective and soft-hearted. He even had a lovely scene vowing to protect the protagonist, the saintess, not because he was honor-bound to, but because all he wanted was to see her safe.)

52.text: (Your mouth is dry for a moment, but you find it within yourself to respond to him.)

53.text: (That much, you can recall. It helps little, though, with what you should respond with.)

54.text: (He looks a bit…stunned? And at the same time, suspicious. You didn’t know kindness could be so controversial.)

55.text: (Or…perhaps for someone like Cecilia, it was.)

56.speaker: Maverick
56.text: Do you really find this appropriate for a friendly family meal together?

57.speaker: "Cecilia"
57.text: Friendly is an overstatement, and “family?” Well that’s simply misleading. I’d rather us pay each other no mind, as always.

58.text: (You tense a little, waiting to see if he’ll snap back. Your luck seems to be on your side today, as he furrows his brows, opens his mouth, and then fails to follow through.)

59.text: (You gain a blessed few moments of silence.)

60.speaker: Maverick
60.text: What a strange thing for you to say. If it was meant to unnerve me, you’ve succeeded.

61.text: (He doesn’t look pleased but he’s not angry either. Just… perplexed.)

62.text: (You can’t fault him, Cecilia never spoke familiarly with him, and anything that left her mouth that wasn’t outright venomous was always mocking in some sort of way.)

63.text: (A guy like Maverick wasn’t the best at reading between the lines and navigating barbed jabs, so when he sighs and gives, you can’t say you’re surprised.)

64.speaker: Maverick
64.text: Does it truly bother you so much, being in the presence of your family?

65.speaker: "Cecilia"
65.text: Is it not also unbefitting of a knight such as yourself to speak to a lady this way?

66.speaker: Maverick
66.text: I would rather see you act like a lady first, in that case.

67.text: (The way he snaps at you is practiced, almost easy. His sharp voice falls into a familiar rhythm.)

68.text: (It seems like this argument isn’t anything new.)

69.speaker: Maverick
69.text: It would reflect poorly on our family name if you were to show such irreverence towards the prince.

70.text: (He rolls his eyes and lets out a deep sigh, sharply mumbling something under his breath.)

71.speaker: Maverick
71.text: [i]…Although knowing your infatuation, perhaps I should be more worried about the irreverence you show towards anyone that [b]isn’t[/b] him.[/i]

72.text: (Ah yes, of course—you remember this too. Cecilia’s fiancé, the crown prince.)

73.text: (His name escapes you at the moment. It seems the fog in your head has not completely dissipated…)

75.text: (For now all you can recall is a well-groomed head of strawberry blond hair and burning, blue eyes. Strikingly handsome, but aren’t they all?)

76.text: (It seems that while you were wondering how to respond, Maverick’s already moved onto a chat with his—err—[i]your[/i] father, which you suppose is his way of telling you that the conversation is over.)

78.text: (Alcinder Antirrhinum de Karmina, head of the Karmina household, Marquess and…not much else, really. He had a scant couple of mentions in [i]Full Blossom[/i], picked up in the periphery of Maverick’s route every once in a while.)

79.text: (Now though, when you look at him, all you see is an imposing steel wall. His gaze does not soften, nor does it yield any warmth.)

80.text: (There is a certain softening of the jaw, you notice mildly, when he looks at Maverick. But the tightness returns when his eyes rake your way every once in a while, as if by disdainful accident.)

81.text: (Nonetheless, you sip at your glass while they talk, mouth left dry from your first nerve wracking exchange as “Cecilia.”)

82.text: (Now, more than ever, is when you have to decide the most important part of being a villainess—surely you didn’t forget, did you?)

83.text: (From now on, and going forward, you’ll have to decide just exactly how you’ll act. You’re a woman condemned to death, doomed to fall from grace, fated to be trampled underfoot so the heroine can come out on top.)

84.text: (You know this story, the way it goes. You’ve seen this countless times—you’ve been put in the place of the villainess, and now it’s up to you to find a way to survive.)

85.text: (You can’t count on anyone to help you right off the bat. You’re alone.)

86.text: (You bite back the bitter taste in your mouth at the thought.)

87.text: (...Which means you have to find a way to change that. The way you present yourself, the way you conduct yourself, these all factor into how you’re going to survive.)

88.text: (First and foremost, you need to think of who you must become. If your life depends on a performance, then you better pick a persona that you know you can act out pretty damn well, and one that will actually give you a chance at escaping death.)

89.text: (You do catch more flies with honey, after all, and nothing is sweeter than a woman who makes herself into as little of a threat as possible.)

90.text: (If you’re fortunate enough, people will see this as a spark of humanity within the oh-so detested villainess. She’s quirky, she’s empathetic, she’s [i]interesting.[/i] It’s always good to be interesting… Right?)

92.text: (This kind of meek, shy persona does wonders to arouse pity in the right people. You’ll grovel and lie belly up if that’s what it takes to survive.)

93.text: (In a way, this is tantamount to eliminating every last trace of your “villainess” persona.)

94.text: (People might say [i]‘Oh, she’s finally acting like a proper lady.’[/i] Submitting to authority, proving your willingness to give in. You’d be liked, in the way that man likes an obedient dog…)

96.text: (You know a little about her; cruel, sharp, [i]witty[/i]. All her appearances in [i]Full Blossom[/i] centered around her schemes, her ploys, the way she’d humiliate the protagonist in public.)

97.text: (No wasted words, no wasted effort. If you want to wear her face, you’ll need to sharpen your tongue and save it for when it truly matters. All in this world is beneath you—at least, until it comes to her fiance.)

98.text: (It’s the safest way to behave; if you can even get your act together, that is.)

100.text: (Merit does seem to make the man, in the end.)

101.text: (You’d appear to play hard to get, dodging the advances of the handsome and wealthy male leads whose interests are only piqued as they subsequently push harder. Enviable, but with a target painted on your back.)

103.text: (Maverick wasn’t entirely wrong about his table manners jab… Which one was it again?)

104.text: (All eyes are on the three of you. As Cecilia, even one mistake, one moment of hesitation, would cast way too much unwanted attention on you.)

105.options: I linger and watch to see what Maverick does. Messing up silverware is as good as signing my death warrant.,I'd rather not get caught staring... maybe if I wrack my brain I'll remember something useful.

106.text: (You pick up the same utensils as he does, cautiously watching and picking through the forks, stabbing at your food with the same angle and strength.)

107.text: (But all that effort comes crashing to an early death and an early doom.)

108.text: (Maverick’s fork stops midway to his open mouth as his eyes travel from your own fork to your mouth, and he raises an eyebrow at you.)

109.text: (Before you can jab at him for such an unbecoming sight, Alcinder sets his own fork down and dabs at his mouth carefully.)

110.speaker: Marquess Karmina
110.text: Your etiquette is…lacking today. Adhere to the proper order, or at least seek a tutor if your memory has grown inadequate.

112.text: (You turn to Maverick, happily using the exact same fork as you to eat the exact same thing, completely unaware of his identical blunder.)

113.text: (But Alcinder clearly doesn’t care that his adopted son is going through the same mannerisms as you—for a moment frustration peaks, but you push it down.)

114.text: (Maybe you should just never trust Maverick again. What a farce of a breakfast…)

115.text: (...Though if you mess this up, that gambit will have all been for nothing.)

116.text: (Before you sits a small plate of salad, composed of garden greens and small slices of salted duck. Bits of fruit and nuts are sprinkled all throughout, along with some kind of light dressing. All you need to do is pick the right utensil to use on it. Simple…)

117.text: (Discreetly, you peer up at the other two sitting at the dining table. No one stares at you strangely or makes a comment—well, what do you know, you might just have the makings of nobility in you.)

118.text: (This information will definitely be useful later down the line.)

119.speaker: Maverick
119.text: Oh, will that be your main course Dear Sister?

120.speaker: Maverick
120.text: You know, if you could control your mouth in conversation as well as you do when eating, you’d be the diamond of the season.

122.text: (Well, it may be too late now… You have no choice but to go with the flow and use the wrong fork. If only you had known…)

123.speaker: Maverick
123.text: Dearest Sister, just because something has fruits and nuts, that doesn’t make it a dessert.

125.text: (Well, it may be too late now… You have no choice but to go with the flow and use the wrong fork. If only you had known…)

126.speaker: "Cecilia"
126.text: (At the very least, you got some information out of this embarrassing blunder.)

128.text: (The silence becomes grating enough that you almost want to speak up and break it.)

129.options: Speak up and say something.,Stay silent.

130.text: (Okay, you’ve got this. Shy, subservient, couldn’t hurt a fly.)

131.speaker: "Cecilia"
131.text: Will… Will my fiancé be mad if I’m late?

134.speaker: "Cecilia"
134.text: Of course not! You just…never know what could happen.

135.speaker: Maverick
135.text: It’s common courtesy to be on time. Especially so when it comes to the royal family.

136.speaker: Maverick
136.text: You might not think much of it, given how you come and go on your whims, but even if it’s for a morning greeting, your timeliness shows that you have a vested interest.

137.speaker: Maverick
137.text: Besides, the Karmina Family can’t be made late by things as weak as happenstance. Have some more faith in our servants.

138.text: (Okay, so it’s just a morning greeting. Now wasn’t that easy?)

139.speaker: "Cecilia"
139.text: Oh, I’m thinking of attending to some other business before I go see him.

140.speaker: "Cecilia"
140.text: But I’m sure my dear betrothed can stand to wait a little.

141.speaker: Maverick
141.text: What are you—do you have no respect whatsoever for the crown prince?!

142.speaker: Maverick
142.text: Respect isn’t given to you on account of your name. You have to earn it, and you’re never going to get any by being so flippant with others.

144.speaker: Maverick
144.text: Even a morning greeting holds immense meaning when dictated by royalty.

145.text: (Okay, easy there. At least you know now it’s some sort of morning greeting you have to attend to.)

147.speaker: "Cecilia"
147.text: So, uh, why am I meeting my fiancé again?

149.text: (It seems you’ve rendered him speechless for a moment.)

150.speaker: Maverick
150.text: Is this some sort of—the morning greeting, Cecilia. You have plans with him later today.

151.text: [i](Maverick, you’re going to get wrinkles if you keep frowning like that.)[/i]

152.text: (But fine, you’ll take it. A morning greeting.)

153.speaker: "Cecilia"
153.text: You seem rather invested in how I spend my time. Does the family name truly mean so much to you that a little meeting has you like this?

154.speaker: Maverick
154.text: A little meeting? Surely you jest. You’re greeting the crown prince, not some other noble.

155.speaker: Maverick
155.text: You focus too much on the wrong side of politics. Try being respectful to someone for once, and you might see more results that way.

156.speaker: Maverick
156.text: Even though the other nobles humor you because of Father’s title, doesn’t mean the same will apply to those above us.

157.text: (Disregarding the attack on your character, you think you’ve got it. You’re greeting your fiancé, the crown prince, later today.)

158.speaker: Maverick
158.text: I’m surprised you cared to ask today of all days.

164.speaker: Maverick
164.text: Why do you ask? It seems irrelevant to your interests.

165.text: (Maverick cuts away at the slices of meat served before him, silverware scraping against the plate.)

166.text: (He looks entirely uninterested in whatever it seems that you’re trying to pull.)

167.speaker: Maverick
167.text: I went to sleep. I woke up.

168.speaker: Maverick
168.text: Unfortunately enough for you, I assume.

169.text: (What are you even supposed to say to that?)

170.text: (This seems to be a running theme today, as he furrows his brows and looks a little appalled as to why you would say such a thing.)

171.speaker: Maverick
171.text: The chef is the same, as always. You frequently eat so little I thought you couldn’t stand him.

173.text: (Oh. You have no idea what to say to that.)

174.text: (Yeah. If you’re going to try to mimic the original Cecilia, you might as well just not say anything. No need to rush into this role when you’re still getting the hang of things.)

175.text: (The benefits of speaking up are way outweighed by the costs of doing something wildly out of character.)

176.text: (Your head snaps up when you hear Cecilia’s father set his fork down, dabbing at his mouth delicately.)

178.text: (He doesn’t look at you when he says it, doesn’t even spare you a glance in passing.)

179.text: (Now that you think about it, he hasn’t said a word to you this entire meal. It’s just been Maverick.)

180.speaker: Maverick
180.text: Yes, father. Best of luck with your endeavors today.

181.text: (You suppose you could say something as well, if you wanted to.)

183.text: (You make an attempt to say this as naturally as you imagine someone like Cecilia would, but it seems that it falls flat as Alcinder stares straight ahead rather coldly, without having much emotion to spare.)

184.text: (For a moment you wonder whether he even heard you, but the furrowing of his brow is unmistakable. He’s ignoring you, his own daughter.)

185.speaker: Marquess Karmina
185.text: Maverick, give the captain my regards.

186.text: (And then, he takes his leave. Not even a glance or goodbye for you.)

187.speaker: Maverick
187.text: Is this part of some ploy?

190.speaker: Maverick
190.text: There’s always some sort of reason for your strange behaviors. I’m sure that this time’s no different.

191.speaker: Maverick
191.text: I can’t think of anything just yet, but I don’t doubt you’re up to something again.

192.text: (Well, he’s half right. Doesn’t discount how little he thinks of you though.)

193.speaker: Maverick
193.text: You seem a bit odd today.

195.text: (You jerk away from his touch, almost although it is more out of muscle memory than your own instinct.)

197.speaker: Maverick
197.text: Well, I suppose you seem fine enough.

198.text: (He runs a hand through his hair and looks at you with immeasurable exasperation.)

199.speaker: Maverick
199.text: Is it really that hard to smile nicely every once in a while? To show some emotion other than contempt or smugness?

200.speaker: Maverick
200.text: You never let anyone in... If you were more open or expressive, maybe you’d be more popular.

201.speaker: Maverick
201.text: …Nonetheless, I want to emphasize again to not be late. You’re not just representing yourself, but all of the family.

202.speaker: Maverick
202.text: That’s all I had to say.

203.speaker: Maverick
203.text: And, Cecilia… Maybe if you were less insistent on being off on your own all the time, people would like you more. Leave your room for something other than those ridiculous [i]schemes[/i] of yours and you’ll understand what I mean.

205.text: (Maverick gets to his feet and departs without a moment’s hesitation, leaving you to stare at the space he once occupied.)

207.text: (You, too, set your fork down and get to your feet, walking towards the entrance where the maid from earlier waits.)

208.speaker: Maid
208.text: Allow me to escort you to the carriage, my lady.

209.text: (Right, they see you as [i]her.[/i] It seems your fate henceforth has been set in stone.)

210.text: (You see no other option, so you follow the maid through the same twists and turns of the hallway before you emerge at the front entrance.)

211.text: (You turn around to get a good look at the building that is now your “home.” Your eyes widen.)

212.text: (The estate stretches on behind you, a beautiful expanse of dark Victorian architecture, intricate and delicate. Above it rests a thick, gloomy sky.)

213.text: (You’d have to get used to it all—this sky, these luxuries, this body, and this life soon.)

fake_choice.options: I desperately blink back the tears that have welled up in my eyes. Weakness means death.,I clench my fist so hard it feels like the sharp nails of these foreign hands will draw blood at any moment. Screw this.,I force myself to swallow the bile rising up my throat. Focus!

fake1.text: (Across the table, the man you recognize as Cecilia’s brother scoffs.)

favorite.text: (Of all the routes, you played his the most. During the period you were entrenched in [i]Full Blossom,[/i] no matter how many achievement run throughs you did, you always came back to him, time and time again.)

liked.text: (He might not be your absolute number one favorite, but he was devoted and charming, a bright spot of sunshine in the doom and gloom of stifling aristocratic society. He defied those rigid expectations and norms, upbeat and skilled with his sword.)

fine.text: (Maverick was the best with a sword among the love interests, a renowned soldier and honorable noble. Though a bit stiff at times, he was someone whose appeal lay in his chivalry and steadfast emphasis on fairness.)

late.options: "My deepest apologies for the tardiness.","What's it to you? Mind your business and eat your breakfast.","Why the fuss? Could it be that you missed me?","Okay."

eat.speaker: Maverick
eat.text: Hmm. Your rudeness is particularly excessive today.

ok.speaker: Maverick
ok.text: Ah, yes, the same disdain as always.

resume.speaker: Maverick
resume.text: Regardless, that’s not what’s important. I wanted to remind you to not be late for your meeting with your fiancé today.

type.options: I should be the endearingly naïve and kind type of villainess.,I should be the tough but intelligent and always-on-top villainess.,I should be the meek and always avoiding death flags kind of villainess.,I should try to mimic the original as much as I can.

silly.text: (Yes, this type. The type who wears her heart on her sleeve, a terrible liar whose charm comes from her sincerity.)

meek.text: (Of course, a staple in the genre. The type who avoids every bit of canon she can, only to pique the interest of the people who had previously wronged her.)

mimic.text: (But, with all that being said… It would make more sense to continue to try to imitate Cecilia.)

girlboss.text: (Who could forget this type? The type who becomes a talented mage, a renowned swordsman, or perhaps a cunning businesswoman using knowledge from the future and another world. A self made woman, whose talents far exceed those of the people around her.)

chosen.text: (Moments later, silence descends upon the dining hall as their conversation peters out. Breakfast has been served; it looks fine and delectable, but even as your stomach begs for sustenance, you find yourself hesitant.)

watch.text: (You shoot a glance at Maverick, watching which utensils he picks up first.)

dontwatch.text: (You already scraped through one conversation on etiquette, so you’d love to avoid having another one over table manners.)

forkin.options: The small fork on the very outside to your left.,The slightly bigger fork in the middle to your left.,The smallest fork at the very inside to your left.

outside.text: (You know what they say, work your way in from the outside…or so you heard a long, long time ago. It seems as good of a guess as any, so you pick it up with trepidation and bring it to the crisp green leaves, pushing inwards.)

middle.text: (You make a good pass for the fork in the middle, picking it up with as much confidence as you can muster. As you bring it to the salad, however, you notice the pinprick of stares from Maverick and the Marquis who hold… the forks that were placed on the outside.)

silly_response.speaker: "Cecilia"
silly_response.text: Hm. Your attentions spoil me, my dearest brother.

other_response.speaker: "Cecilia"
other_response.text: Of course my dearest brother. Though I could say the inverse for you.

fork.text: (At the very least, you got some information out of this embarrassing blunder.)

inside.text: (You make a good pass for the fork in the middle, picking it up with as much confidence as you can muster. As you bring it to the salad, however, you notice the pinprick of stares from Maverick and the Marquis who hold… the forks that were placed on the outside.)

mimic_response_2.speaker: "Cecilia"
mimic_response_2.text: And just because a boy wears a suit of armor, that doesn’t make him a man either, now does it my dearest brother?

other_response_2.speaker: "Cecilia"
other_response_2.text: Well I don’t see why it shouldn’t!

meal_returns.text: (The meal begins. As the minutes pass, all that can be heard is the clinking of silverware.)

about.options: Prod about why you're meeting your fiance.,Try to spark a conversation.

fiance_girlboss.text: (Easy, you just need to be confident about it.)

fiance_silly.text: (If you’re going to ask, best to not think too hard about it.)

fiance_mimic.text: (Now you only need to think of the most natural way to ask.)

spark_silly.speaker: "Cecilia"
spark_silly.text: So…the food is pretty yummy today, isn’t it?

spark_mimic.text: (You try to think of something to say, but your mind just keeps pulling up blanks.)

spark_reroute.text: (The rest of breakfast proceeds quietly, which you’re thankful for.)

nobye.text: (Only Maverick is left now, sitting silently across from you. You peek at him for a moment to gauge what he could be feeling, but his face betrays no emotion.)

ooc_over.text: (For a moment he stays silent, eyes narrowed at you in a way that makes the hairs on the back of your neck stand up. You recall, in that moment, how good he is with a sword.)

ooc_3.speaker: Maverick
ooc_3.text: Have you not gotten enough sleep or something?

ooc_0.speaker: Maverick
ooc_0.text: You never change, do you? It’s always that same stiff expression of yours.

amuse.options: Probably amused. I mean maybe if Cecilia listened to him she—and by extension I—wouldn’t be in this situation in the first place.,I have no idea... and honestly I’m not even going to try to puzzle through that last bit of advice he left me with.,No. Definitely upset. If it was that easy I’d have done it already—but it isn’t. Why can’t he understand that?
